title: Arctomecon humilis
text:
Arctomecon humilis is a rare species of <a href="Papaveraceae">poppy</a> called bearclaw poppy or dwarf bearclaw-poppy. It is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Washington%20County%2C%20Utah">Washington County, Utah</a>, in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> of America. It is a federally listed <a href="endangered%20species">endangered species</a> limited to barren, heavily <a href="Gypsum">gypsiferous</a> soils in the immediate vicinity of <a href="St.%20George%2C%20Utah">St. George, Utah</a>. Only a half-dozen populations are known, several of which are adjacent to or even within the urbanized area.
"Arctomecon humilis" is a <a href="taproot">taproot</a>ed perennial herb producing stout, waxy stems that grow 15 to 25 centimeters tall. Waxy blue-green leaves with rounded teeth are located around the base of the plant. Each <a href="Scape%20%28botany%29">scape</a>-like stem has one or two ivory-white <a href="flower">flower</a>s that have orange-yellow stamens. The ovoid shaped <a href="fruit">fruit</a>s produce up to 30 or sometimes more, shiny black <a href="seed">seed</a>s.
It is pollinated by the rare <a href="solitary%20bee">solitary bee</a> species "<a href="Perdita%20meconis">Perdita meconis</a>".
